text: I remember I woke up and got in the
shower to take my you know take my
shower do a shampoo and I couldn't
breathe enough to I had to get out of
the shower before I even got the soap
out of my hair and that really scared me
struggling out of the shower and short
of breath Jean ramas got into her car
and drove to her doctor's office in
nearby Creston Iowa and I did something
that I had never done before in my
entire life I parked in a handicap
parking place without a sticker or
anything inside the clinic she collapsed
on the couch they asked me if I was
alright but of course you know I'm proud
and and I just simply oh I'm fine gene
has chronic obstructive pulmonary
disease or COPD a term referring to to
lung diseases chronic bronchitis and
emphysema her problems began like they
do for an estimated 85% of those
afflicted with COPD with a smoking habit
I smoked for 30 years I quit in 1992 at
the time I was also pretty heavy and
besides that I also have type 2 diabetes
and I really wasn't paying a whole lot
of attention frankly to either one of
those I was just kind of living my life
and kind of going along there's the cake
gene says she spent three days in the
hospital there she underwent a treatment
regimen of steroids antibiotics
bronchodilators and oxygen and I made
the mistake at that point of asking my
doctor how do I fix this he but he kind
of looked at me and he said well gene
you know if you'd lose some weight
because I was almost 300 pounds at that
point if you'd lose some weight a lot of
your problems will get better they
aren't going to go away but they will
get better and something in the way he
said it or the way he looked he swears
up and down that he didn't that he
didn't mean it this way but I perceived
that he didn't think I either could or
would well I was mad and I was scared
and those those two things really are
pretty powerful motivators it just made
us about 12 million people in the United
States with chronic obstructive
pulmonary disease but that probably
underestimates the
total numbers there may be as many as
twice as many individuals with this
disorder it currently is the fourth
killer in the United States and it's
estimated by 2020 it'll be the third
killer ypres today half of COPD patients
are under 65 and it has become
increasingly a disease of women a
reflection of their increased smoking in
previous decades in 2000 for the first
time more women than men died over
hospitalized for the disease it's a
message not lost on Jean Ramos who now
works out every day I do two sets of
twelve of those and two sets of knee
raises now I have to recover for
probably longer than most people because
I get winded and I've got to catch my
breath in and get back to the point
where I can breathe again while COPD is
incurable
it is not untreatable treatments often
include anti-inflammation medicines
drugs to open the airways into
antibiotics for infections some need
oxygen and many need dietary advice and
in extreme situations some patients
benefit from surgery to remove diseased
sections of lung oxygen is good
but above all people with COPD need
exercise it may be ten or fifteen years
ago there was a question does physical
rehabilitation help patients with
chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
now we no longer ask ourselves this
question
Neal Schachter is the medical director
of the pulmonary rehab program at Mount
Sinai in New York City we know that as a
result of this endurance improves their
symptoms get better we're able to let
them lead more productive lives do more
with what they have patients with
trouble breathing often think they are
just out of shape and don't realize they
have COPD this is one of the reasons
that COPD is often under diagnosed
blasts it up but the test for COPD is a
simple procedure known as spirometry
shown here in doctor Crystal's office at
the Wilde Cornell Medical Center in
Manhattan even though these tests are
easy to perform and recommended for
high-risk patients many doctors don't
bother some say that smoking is
considered such an intractable addiction
that they felt helpless to do anything
about it this brings up another more
daunting issue that many COPD sufferers
face stigma they feel a bit guilty
because they brought it on themselves in
a way because they smoke cigarettes I
tell people I have emphysema and very
often the first question that somebody
will ask is did you smoke yes I did
smoke for 30 years but I quit in 1992
and I guess my feeling is that yeah
obviously what I did probably did have a
great deal to do with my getting this
disease in the first place
hooked on exercise Jean Rama sticks to
her daily workout with a vigor and
commitment that she realizes may be out
of reach of many with COPD her lungs
will never return to normal but she is
striving to live a full and independent
life I guess I've come to realize that I
have to do this if I'm going to keep my
energy level up and continue to work and
live the way I want to live then I have
to do
this there just isn't any choice
